Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Wellman-HST Summer Institute for Biomedical Optics

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The Wellman-HST Summer Institute for Biomedical Optics, a new REU site supported by the NSF Division of Engineering Education and Centers, will admit ten undergraduate students to work on cutting-edge research on biomedical optics. Students will pursue full-time laboratory research for nine weeks from June to August at the Wellman Center for Photomedicine at Massachusetts General Hospital. It provides a highly multidisciplinary environment at the interface of laboratory innovations and real-world applications. The faculty with backgrounds in physics, chemistry, and engineering will serve as mentors. A variety of research projects are offered in diverse, yet cohesive, themes in the field of biomedical optics, with emphasis on multidisciplinary approaches that integrate optical physics and engineering with biological questions and medical problems. The research program will enhance the ability of students to undertake interdisciplinary research on a broad range of cutting-edge topics including optical coherence tomography, bio-integrated photonic devices, cell lasers, biomechanics, and photodynamic therapy. Students who produce significant results will be identified and encouraged to submit abstracts to annual conferences with full travel supports. In addition to research, students attend lectures, seminars, and professional development workshops on presentation, ethics, and intellectual properties. All student participants are accommodated in the dormitory at the MIT campus in close proximity to the labs and lecture sites, and they participate in various social activities. Stipends and travel supports will be provided. The vibrant summer program will make their summer experience go way beyond what could be provided by a typical research experience in a single lab.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Biomedical optics is a rapidly growing field, well poised to impact biological sciences and human health. Students will witness how innovative research in the lab can help solve real-world problems and thus provide tangible benefits to the society we live in. This experience will help students gain a broader and deeper perspective on research and possibly further motivate the students to pursue a future in interdisciplinary science and engineering. Interactions with mentors provide role models to the students while helping them evaluate their own future career paths. The REU site will also have a positive impact on faculty mentors by fostering active interactions and collaborations. Students will interact with overseas summer students in other ongoing international programs, building global networks. In turn, by providing positive experiences, this interaction can increase the international recognition of science and engineering in the U.S. by attracting talented undergraduates from overseas to the U.S. for higher education. The REU site is well positioned to become a national and international model for highly interdisciplinary and intense summer research experiences for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this program was to provide undergraduate students with a unique opportunity to explore biomedical optics in a multidisciplinary environment at the interface of laboratory innovations and real-world applications. Additionally, the program aimed to inspire the students to pursue advanced research, education, and careers in science and engineering.

The program admitted 10 junior and senior students each year across the nation. 50% of students were female, and 23% were from underrepresented populations.

The program strived to provide them with a positive experience in cutting-edge research, a sense of accomplishment, and the joy of scientifically interacting with peers and professionals.

For the duration of 9 weeks, students were immersed in full-time mentored research. Each student had a faculty mentor, who is a faculty member of Harvard Medical School, and a postdoc and/or graduate student for daily supervision. In the first week, students write and submit research proposals. At Week 4-5, students share research progress in a workshop and receive feedbacks on presentation. In the final week, the program organized a Poster Day event. All students present their posters to over 100 attendees and, also, gave formal presentations to a group of judges, who select two winners for the Best Presentation Awards. The poster presentation is followed by certificate award ceremony.

The students attended didactic lectures organized to introduce students to the subject of biomedical optics. Biomedical optics is a rapidly growing field, making significant impact on the biological sciences and human health. It is readily accessible to undergraduates using the material covered in introductory courses in physics, engineering, and biology.

In addition, the program organized several social networking activities, such as ice breaking at the Harvard square in the first week, trip to a Red Sox baseball game at the Fenway Park in Week 3, and eat-out night in Week 7.  

The students contributed to a total of 10 research papers published in scientific journals and 9 poster presentations in conferences.

The students witnessed how innovative research in the lab can help solve real-world problems and thus provide tangible benefits to the society we live in. These experiences will help students gain a broader and deeper perspective on science and engineering and possibly further motivate the students to pursue a career in research and engineering.

Interactions with mentors, graduate students, and other researchers provide role models to the students while helping them evaluate their own career paths. The networks the students built with their mentors and peers will also serve the students in their careers.

The students were given the opportunity to interact with international students in the Summer Institute and build global networks that may serve them well in their future careers. In turn, by providing positive experiences, this interaction is expected to increase the international recognition of science and engineering in the U.S. by attracting talented undergraduates from overseas for higher education in the U.S. and promoting international collaboration.
